column5: I do not normally write reviews for any products I buy online, but hope that my review contributes and helps other people decide to purchase Cuckoo's multi-cooker with no doubt. column3: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2019
column5: tl:dr - Cuckoo pressure cooker timer is for total cook time, not time at pressure. This is contrary to how all pressure cooker recipes are written, making this electric pressure cooker essentially pointless for following pressure cooker recipes.I took a chance on this Cuckoo Multi Pressure Cooker over the ubiquitous instant pot. I was excited about the possibility of the automatic steam valve and overall aesthetic. Unfortunately it is getting returned.All pressure cooker recipes are written and based on time-at-pressure.This is done because once a pressure cooker has reached pressure it is at more or less a known temperature (Similar to preheating an oven). The time it takes to get to pressure will vary depending on the size of the pressure cooker, how full it is, and the actual makeup of the stuff (More liquid versus more solid).To account for this - most (probably all - I double checked the manuals for 4 popular brands) other pressure cookers have a timer that doesn't start counting down until the pressure cooker actually reaches pressurization.Design Defect Number 1Unfortunately the timer on this Cuckoo works differently - the timer starts counting down as soon as you start cooking, and doesn't take into account whether the cooker has reached pressurization or not. This presents two big challenges.Following recipes written for other pressure cookers simply will not work, because the pressure cooking times given on those recipes assumes the timer will not start counting down until the pressure cooker reaches the pressurization stage.One example of the result of this - All pressure cooker recipes require some liquid for the pressure cooker to pressurize and work. This can just be plain water or a broth or sauce. In this cuckoo, starting with cold versus warm liquids would affect the outcome of a recipe because the starting temperature of these liquids would affect how long it takes for the unit to come up to pressure. In other pressure cookers, this could still somewhat affect the outcome, but the effect would be much less since the most important thing in pressure cooking is time at pressure.Design Defect Number 2The machine does not give you any indication whether it is at pressure or not - so even if you wanted to take your own run at adjusting recipes written for other pressure cookers, it's impossible (or at least would be very difficult) for you to know how much to adjust the recipe by, because you basically have to just guess whether it is at pressure or not.I don't know how Cuckoo overlooked something so fundamental to pressure cooking. I would not recommend this unit to anyone.

column3: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2018
column5: This is an excellent all-around cooker and it does a great job on *most* things.  If you are a rice aficionado, it may not be as satisfying as a dedicated Cuckoo Rice Cooker - We have one too and, IMHO, it is the best out there.  If you only want one cooker, this is definitely the one to get - far better quality than the cheaper versions.  One caveat: Cuckoo's philosophy for this cooker is, "I Cook, You Rest" which means that their default settings for time and temperature will work in most cases.  You do have the ability to change cooking time for all options but temperature is only adjustable for about half of the options.  While this sounds like a limitation, in practice it is not.  Just be mindful that the temperature setting options are by "level", not degrees Fahrenheit.  That means there's a learning curve but once you get used to this, you'll love this cooker.  One other thing... Do not be tempted to fill the pot above the maximum mark with any liquid - particularly if you are using it in a pressure cook mode.  Doing so guarantees that liquid will spew out of the steam vent and overflow the collection cup - Spoken from experience.I do have one negative:  The user manual is not particularly helpful for cooking practices and the cookbook that's packed in with the cooker is only marginally better.  You WILL have to experiment so don't invite guests for dinner until you've played around a bit.

column5: I've heard rave reviews, particularly from the Korean community both online and in-person about the Cuckoo line of multi-purpose pressure cookers so we decided to give this one a try. On the first impression, build quality is great with solid plastics and metals with included accessories like a measuring cup and rice paddle. We purchased this with the intention of primarily using it as a rice cooker and after a few rounds of cooking and keeping rice warm, the overall impression goes down. The thing speaks to you throughout the whole process from selection of function, pressurizing of the cooker, and even the release of the pressure with simulated pressure release sounds.If purchasing this for use primarily for cooking rice I would steer clear and go for a Zojirushi. It can cook rice, but not to the standard of an almost $200 rice cooker. Uneven cooking, some parts cooked, overcooked, and even undercooked. The keep-warm function has to be the worst. Steam isn't necessarily being released because of the locking mechanism meaning but even when not locked completely and kept on the keep warm function, actual puddles of steam would collect and continue to be absorbed by the rice. By the end of a 3 hour keep warm, almost all the rice would be too soggy to even enjoy.If you plan on using this rice cooker to cook small batches of rice which would be consumed right away this could be the solution of freeing up counter space for a rice cooker/pressure cooker/slow cooker making it perfect for smaller kitchens. Otherwise, if you're particular with your rice and prefer to keep rice warm for several hours skip this pressure cooker and shop for a dedicated rice cooker.

column5: I've had the Cuckoo ICOOK Q5 Premium for about 2 weeks now and so far I like it more than my Instant Pot. With smarter technology, this multi-cooker is versatile, easy to use and stylish. The function buttons are simple and intuitive. Use just one "Menu" button to cycle through the different built-in programs: SOUP, MEAT, VEGETABLES, RICE, PORRIDGE, BROWNING FRY, MULTI COOK, STEAM COOK, SLOW COOK, AUTO CLEAN and then use the "Selection" button to adjust the cooking time. Press "Cook" to start...super easy!Two differentiating features intrigued me right away:#1 Auto Clean - releases a strong jet of steam to clean and sanitize the interior of the multi-cooker. I love this function and used it to sanitize my new cooker before cooking food for the first time. Since then I've used it multiple times.#2 Adjustable Keep Warm - lets you set the temperature from 154-176 degrees Fahrenheit. I like having the ability to adjust this and have found the static "Keep Warm" can be too hot for certain foods.Pressure cooking, steaming and cooking rice are the functions I use most and having all of these in one appliance is a huge win. I tested the "Rice" mode first and it cooked jasmine white rice perfectly in about 30 minutes. The unique feature to note about the "Rice" function is it pressure cooks and then steams the rice.Using the "Meat" mode, I pressure cooked 8 sticky rice and banana cakes (thick roll cakes) for 45 minutes and they were cooked perfectly. (If I had boiled these on the stove top, it would have taken about 1 1/2 - 2 hours, a huge time-savings.)I like the steam plate is included and not an accessory for additional purchase. So far I've steamed broccoli using Level 1 for 15 minutes and they came out soft but not mushy. My wish for the "Steam Cook" function would be an option to steam for less than 15 minutes. Some foods are delicate and don't require 15 minutes of steaming. The workaround is to cancel when the needed cook time has elapsed, not a huge inconvenience.I thought the 5-quart pot would be a bit small compared to my 6-quart Instant Pot. So far, it hasn't been an issue. I will have to make a few more family-sized recipes to weigh-in on this further. Perhaps Cuckoo will offer an 8 or even 10-quart multi-cooker size in the near future.I like the look and design of the Cuckoo ICOOK Q5 Premium Multi Cooker. It's an egg-shaped, minimalist design and quite attractive. It's a nice appliance to display on the kitchen counter.The Smart Voice Guide is novel. She announces what the multi cooker is doing like "Steaming is starting" and "Rice is complete". It's really cute and a great way to monitor cooking without having to watch it constantly.In addition to the instruction manual, the multi cooker comes with a 30-recipe cookbook. The recipes are easy and a great way to get acquainted with the cooker and enjoy some yummy dishes. There are also more recipes offered on the Cuckoo website.

column5: Before I got this Cuckoo multi pressure cooker, I had never used a pressure cooker before. Sure, I HAVE an old fashioned pressure cooker. I am not sure where I got it, but I got it decades ago and it sits quietly on the shelf where I occasionally look at it. But I've always considered it's reason d'etre to be unclear, and the idea of many bars of pressure inside this pot scary.So maybe I wasn't the obvious target for this new do-everything-for-you pressure cooker. Or maybe I was EXACTLY the correct target.Anyway, intrigued by the idea that it does do everything--both pressure cook and release the steam automatically and safely afterwards--I took a flyer.I should add that it doesn't just generically pressure cook. It can also braise/fry in the pot. Which I found fantastically convenient, since it means you can truly make a "one pot" dinner.OK, so for my first attempt at pressure cooking, I went with pulled pork. That's a full day enterprise using other methods. With the pressure cooker, it takes about 1 hour and 15 minutes. I took a 3 pound pork shoulder, added a few tablespoons of oil, browned both sides using the "browning fry"  setting, tossed in some bbq sauce and water, and let the "pressure cook" setting do its magic for 1:15. The machine talks to you (and plays celebratory music--cute), and at 1:15 it let me know everything was done. And it was! I took out the now fully cooked port shoulder, pulled it apart with two forks (could also use a food processor or blender for this), tossed the result back in the pot with part of the sauce that the shoulder had cooked with and a little more bbq sauce, brought it to a simmer using "browning fry" and served. The result: Perfection! (See photo of the original pork shoulder and the final result).It was really really easy and it worked just as it was supposed to. There was never any worry about "is it too soon to release the pressure?"This spoken by someone who has NEVER used a pressure cooker before.Some additional comments:1) It runs SUPER quiet. In fact, the only time I really knew that it was running is either when it said something to me (like "done") or when it was letting off steam. During most of the cooking process, you could forget it's running.2) The documentation could be a bit better about the various cooking modes. Some are obvious, such as "pressure cook", "slow cook", "browning fry" and "clean". (Yeah, it has a self-cleaning mode. Just add 3 cups of water and press start--very nice). But what exactly does "Multi Cook" do? It's never explained anywhere in the manual, and even online I couldn't find a straight answer.3) The parts that come in contact with the food (the bowl, the interior cover) are easily removable for cleaning. The bowl is non-stick on the entire surface (not just the bottom like the cheapo competitors like InstantPot) which is convenient.4) It's a fairly large appliance. Bigger than a bread machine, and it needs a decent amount of clearance above the cooker for the top to open.5) There are many safety interlocks and checks, along with automatic pressure valves that will let off steam if needed to keep the pressure from getting too high.6) Quality is top notch. Everything fits together with tight tolerances and everything works smoothly out of the box. This is made in South Korea, not China, and it's of the expected high quality.7) If you have never used one of these before (raises hand) expect to spend at least half an hour just familiarizing yourself with the cooker and reading through the fairly lengthy instructions.8) Cooking modes include: Pressure cooking, steam cooking, slow cooking, browning/frying.9) Specific food type modes include: soup, meat, vegetables, porridge, rice,10) There's also a "keep warm" mode for delayed serving. And you can set a timer so that cooking starts in the future (up to 12 hour delay).11) As a FYI, here's a list of sample food types for which the manufacturer provides cooking modes/settings. As you can infer, this is a jack of all trades: cauliflower and potato soup; french onion soup; ginger and butternut squash soup; black bean soup; baby back ribs; one pot beans, sausage and greens; teriyaki pork loin; eggplant and roasted red pepper dip; zucchini ratatouille; brown butter fingerling potatoes; horseradish mashed potatoes; breakfast porridge; purple yam barley porridge; jasmine rice; sausage and cheese frittata; mashed potatoes; chile Colorado; creme brulee; New England clam chowder; red lentil chili; steamed artichokes; crab legs; steamed ribs with glutinous rice; turnip cake; Korean steamed ribs; pomegranate sauce; sour cream; yogurt. And obviously the list can go on and on.12) The LCD screen is big and bright. There aren't that many buttons, and selection is mostly done by scrolling through the options on the LCD screen. It's pretty easy-to-use and intuitive--something that does not appear to be the case with many of the competitors.One the whole, this is one fantastic appliance that actually justifies the precious counter space it takes up. Highly recommended!

column5: tl:dr - Cuckoo pressure cooker timer is for total cook time, not time at pressure. This is contrary to how all pressure cooker recipes are written, making this electric pressure cooker essentially pointless for following pressure cooker recipes.I took a chance on this Cuckoo Multi Pressure Cooker over the ubiquitous instant pot. I was excited about the possibility of the automatic steam valve and overall aesthetic. Unfortunately it is getting returned.All pressure cooker recipes are written and based on time-at-pressure.This is done because once a pressure cooker has reached pressure it is at more or less a known temperature (Similar to preheating an oven). The time it takes to get to pressure will vary depending on the size of the pressure cooker, how full it is, and the actual makeup of the stuff (More liquid versus more solid).To account for this - most (probably all - I double checked the manuals for 4 popular brands) other pressure cookers have a timer that doesn't start counting down until the pressure cooker actually reaches pressurization.Design Defect Number 1Unfortunately the timer on this Cuckoo works differently - the timer starts counting down as soon as you start cooking, and doesn't take into account whether the cooker has reached pressurization or not. This presents two big challenges.Following recipes written for other pressure cookers simply will not work, because the pressure cooking times given on those recipes assumes the timer will not start counting down until the pressure cooker reaches the pressurization stage.One example of the result of this - All pressure cooker recipes require some liquid for the pressure cooker to pressurize and work. This can just be plain water or a broth or sauce. In this cuckoo, starting with cold versus warm liquids would affect the outcome of a recipe because the starting temperature of these liquids would affect how long it takes for the unit to come up to pressure. In other pressure cookers, this could still somewhat affect the outcome, but the effect would be much less since the most important thing in pressure cooking is time at pressure.Design Defect Number 2The machine does not give you any indication whether it is at pressure or not - so even if you wanted to take your own run at adjusting recipes written for other pressure cookers, it's impossible (or at least would be very difficult) for you to know how much to adjust the recipe by, because you basically have to just guess whether it is at pressure or not.I don't know how Cuckoo overlooked something so fundamental to pressure cooking. I would not recommend this unit to anyone.

column5: tl:dr - Cuckoo pressure cooker timer is for total cook time, not time at pressure. This is contrary to how all pressure cooker recipes are written, making this electric pressure cooker essentially pointless for following pressure cooker recipes.I took a chance on this Cuckoo Multi Pressure Cooker over the ubiquitous instant pot. I was excited about the possibility of the automatic steam valve and overall aesthetic. Unfortunately it is getting returned.All pressure cooker recipes are written and based on time-at-pressure.This is done because once a pressure cooker has reached pressure it is at more or less a known temperature (Similar to preheating an oven). The time it takes to get to pressure will vary depending on the size of the pressure cooker, how full it is, and the actual makeup of the stuff (More liquid versus more solid).To account for this - most (probably all - I double checked the manuals for 4 popular brands) other pressure cookers have a timer that doesn't start counting down until the pressure cooker actually reaches pressurization.Design Defect Number 1Unfortunately the timer on this Cuckoo works differently - the timer starts counting down as soon as you start cooking, and doesn't take into account whether the cooker has reached pressurization or not. This presents two big challenges.Following recipes written for other pressure cookers simply will not work, because the pressure cooking times given on those recipes assumes the timer will not start counting down until the pressure cooker reaches the pressurization stage.One example of the result of this - All pressure cooker recipes require some liquid for the pressure cooker to pressurize and work. This can just be plain water or a broth or sauce. In this cuckoo, starting with cold versus warm liquids would affect the outcome of a recipe because the starting temperature of these liquids would affect how long it takes for the unit to come up to pressure. In other pressure cookers, this could still somewhat affect the outcome, but the effect would be much less since the most important thing in pressure cooking is time at pressure.Design Defect Number 2The machine does not give you any indication whether it is at pressure or not - so even if you wanted to take your own run at adjusting recipes written for other pressure cookers, it's impossible (or at least would be very difficult) for you to know how much to adjust the recipe by, because you basically have to just guess whether it is at pressure or not.I don't know how Cuckoo overlooked something so fundamental to pressure cooking. I would not recommend this unit to anyone.

column5: I've had the Cuckoo ICOOK Q5 Premium for about 2 weeks now and so far I like it more than my Instant Pot. With smarter technology, this multi-cooker is versatile, easy to use and stylish. The function buttons are simple and intuitive. Use just one "Menu" button to cycle through the different built-in programs: SOUP, MEAT, VEGETABLES, RICE, PORRIDGE, BROWNING FRY, MULTI COOK, STEAM COOK, SLOW COOK, AUTO CLEAN and then use the "Selection" button to adjust the cooking time. Press "Cook" to start...super easy!Two differentiating features intrigued me right away:#1 Auto Clean - releases a strong jet of steam to clean and sanitize the interior of the multi-cooker. I love this function and used it to sanitize my new cooker before cooking food for the first time. Since then I've used it multiple times.#2 Adjustable Keep Warm - lets you set the temperature from 154-176 degrees Fahrenheit. I like having the ability to adjust this and have found the static "Keep Warm" can be too hot for certain foods.Pressure cooking, steaming and cooking rice are the functions I use most and having all of these in one appliance is a huge win. I tested the "Rice" mode first and it cooked jasmine white rice perfectly in about 30 minutes. The unique feature to note about the "Rice" function is it pressure cooks and then steams the rice.Using the "Meat" mode, I pressure cooked 8 sticky rice and banana cakes (thick roll cakes) for 45 minutes and they were cooked perfectly. (If I had boiled these on the stove top, it would have taken about 1 1/2 - 2 hours, a huge time-savings.)I like the steam plate is included and not an accessory for additional purchase. So far I've steamed broccoli using Level 1 for 15 minutes and they came out soft but not mushy. My wish for the "Steam Cook" function would be an option to steam for less than 15 minutes. Some foods are delicate and don't require 15 minutes of steaming. The workaround is to cancel when the needed cook time has elapsed, not a huge inconvenience.I thought the 5-quart pot would be a bit small compared to my 6-quart Instant Pot. So far, it hasn't been an issue. I will have to make a few more family-sized recipes to weigh-in on this further. Perhaps Cuckoo will offer an 8 or even 10-quart multi-cooker size in the near future.I like the look and design of the Cuckoo ICOOK Q5 Premium Multi Cooker. It's an egg-shaped, minimalist design and quite attractive. It's a nice appliance to display on the kitchen counter.The Smart Voice Guide is novel. She announces what the multi cooker is doing like "Steaming is starting" and "Rice is complete". It's really cute and a great way to monitor cooking without having to watch it constantly.In addition to the instruction manual, the multi cooker comes with a 30-recipe cookbook. The recipes are easy and a great way to get acquainted with the cooker and enjoy some yummy dishes. There are also more recipes offered on the Cuckoo website.

column5: Before I got this Cuckoo multi pressure cooker, I had never used a pressure cooker before. Sure, I HAVE an old fashioned pressure cooker. I am not sure where I got it, but I got it decades ago and it sits quietly on the shelf where I occasionally look at it. But I've always considered it's reason d'etre to be unclear, and the idea of many bars of pressure inside this pot scary.So maybe I wasn't the obvious target for this new do-everything-for-you pressure cooker. Or maybe I was EXACTLY the correct target.Anyway, intrigued by the idea that it does do everything--both pressure cook and release the steam automatically and safely afterwards--I took a flyer.I should add that it doesn't just generically pressure cook. It can also braise/fry in the pot. Which I found fantastically convenient, since it means you can truly make a "one pot" dinner.OK, so for my first attempt at pressure cooking, I went with pulled pork. That's a full day enterprise using other methods. With the pressure cooker, it takes about 1 hour and 15 minutes. I took a 3 pound pork shoulder, added a few tablespoons of oil, browned both sides using the "browning fry"  setting, tossed in some bbq sauce and water, and let the "pressure cook" setting do its magic for 1:15. The machine talks to you (and plays celebratory music--cute), and at 1:15 it let me know everything was done. And it was! I took out the now fully cooked port shoulder, pulled it apart with two forks (could also use a food processor or blender for this), tossed the result back in the pot with part of the sauce that the shoulder had cooked with and a little more bbq sauce, brought it to a simmer using "browning fry" and served. The result: Perfection! (See photo of the original pork shoulder and the final result).It was really really easy and it worked just as it was supposed to. There was never any worry about "is it too soon to release the pressure?"This spoken by someone who has NEVER used a pressure cooker before.Some additional comments:1) It runs SUPER quiet. In fact, the only time I really knew that it was running is either when it said something to me (like "done") or when it was letting off steam. During most of the cooking process, you could forget it's running.2) The documentation could be a bit better about the various cooking modes. Some are obvious, such as "pressure cook", "slow cook", "browning fry" and "clean". (Yeah, it has a self-cleaning mode. Just add 3 cups of water and press start--very nice). But what exactly does "Multi Cook" do? It's never explained anywhere in the manual, and even online I couldn't find a straight answer.3) The parts that come in contact with the food (the bowl, the interior cover) are easily removable for cleaning. The bowl is non-stick on the entire surface (not just the bottom like the cheapo competitors like InstantPot) which is convenient.4) It's a fairly large appliance. Bigger than a bread machine, and it needs a decent amount of clearance above the cooker for the top to open.5) There are many safety interlocks and checks, along with automatic pressure valves that will let off steam if needed to keep the pressure from getting too high.6) Quality is top notch. Everything fits together with tight tolerances and everything works smoothly out of the box. This is made in South Korea, not China, and it's of the expected high quality.7) If you have never used one of these before (raises hand) expect to spend at least half an hour just familiarizing yourself with the cooker and reading through the fairly lengthy instructions.8) Cooking modes include: Pressure cooking, steam cooking, slow cooking, browning/frying.9) Specific food type modes include: soup, meat, vegetables, porridge, rice,10) There's also a "keep warm" mode for delayed serving. And you can set a timer so that cooking starts in the future (up to 12 hour delay).11) As a FYI, here's a list of sample food types for which the manufacturer provides cooking modes/settings. As you can infer, this is a jack of all trades: cauliflower and potato soup; french onion soup; ginger and butternut squash soup; black bean soup; baby back ribs; one pot beans, sausage and greens; teriyaki pork loin; eggplant and roasted red pepper dip; zucchini ratatouille; brown butter fingerling potatoes; horseradish mashed potatoes; breakfast porridge; purple yam barley porridge; jasmine rice; sausage and cheese frittata; mashed potatoes; chile Colorado; creme brulee; New England clam chowder; red lentil chili; steamed artichokes; crab legs; steamed ribs with glutinous rice; turnip cake; Korean steamed ribs; pomegranate sauce; sour cream; yogurt. And obviously the list can go on and on.12) The LCD screen is big and bright. There aren't that many buttons, and selection is mostly done by scrolling through the options on the LCD screen. It's pretty easy-to-use and intuitive--something that does not appear to be the case with many of the competitors.One the whole, this is one fantastic appliance that actually justifies the precious counter space it takes up. Highly recommended!
